title: 108_hr5046
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pentagon 9/11 Memorial Commemorative Coin Act of 2004". It includes findings related to the commemoration of the 9/11 attacks. The Congress finds that the Pentagon was completed in 1943 during World War II. September 11, 2001, was a tragic day for the United States and the Pentagon, where 184 individuals lost their lives. A memorial is planned to honor the victims, to be built on 1.93 acres near the Pentagon, with a target completion date of late fall 2006. Around $30,000,000 needs to be raised from the private sector for the memorial construction. The surcharge proceeds from the sale of a commemorative coin would raise funding for the construction and maintenance of the Pentagon Memorial in remembrance of those who lost their lives on September 11, 2001. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins with specific weights and diameters as outlined in the Act. The number of gold coins minted will be determined based on the number of innocent individuals confirmed or presumed to have been killed in the 9/11 Pentagon attack. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can only use metals from natural deposits in the US or its territories. Congress acknowledges the effectiveness of certain limitations in the Code. The commemorative coins serve to bring stability to the markets, maximize demand, and ensure broad private support. The program aims to remember the victims of September 11, 2001, and raise funds for the Pentagon Memorial Fund quickly. The Act justifies exempting coins produced under it from certain limitations in the law. This exemption applies to specific sections of the United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the courage of those involved in the events of September 11, 2001, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "United States of America". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various entities. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the courage of those involved in the events of September 11, 2001, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "United States of America". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Memorial Fund, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the courage of those involved in the events of September 11, 2001, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "United States of America". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which will be issued in proof quality. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike a particular quality of coins, except for half dollar coins which can be struck at any number of facilities. The Secretary will start issuing coins soon after the enactment of the Act and will stop issuing them after one year. The Secretary will issue coins under the Act in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins in proof quality. Coins will be issued within a year of the Act's enactment and no coins will be issued after that period. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The Secretary shall sell coins issued under section 3(a) at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales at a discount are allowed, and prepaid orders are accepted with reasonable discounts. The Secretary will issue a $50 coin under section 3(a)(1) for free to the next of kin or personal representative of individuals identified under section 3(b)(2). The Speaker of the House and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate will arrange for the presentation of these gold coins on behalf of Congress. The Secretary will add surcharges to coin sales under this Act: $100 for $50 gold coins, $10 for $1 coins, and $5 for half dollar coins. Surcharges will go to the Pentagon Memorial Fund for a memorial construction in Arlington, Virginia, and will be audited as per the requirements of the United States Code.
